headline: Best Baked French Fries
description: The best baked French fries are deliciously crispy, golden, and garlicky — you won't be able to resist! Double the recipe if you're feeding a crowd.

video.description: See how to make crispy, crunchy, healthier French fries.
video.name: Best Baked Fries

name: Best Baked French Fries
recipeIngredient: 6 Yukon Gold potatoes, cut into thick fries
1 teaspoon garlic powder, or more to taste
1 teaspoon salt, or more to taste
1 teaspoon ground black pepper, or more to taste

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C). Line a baking sheet with aluminum foil; spray with cooking spray.
Place sliced potatoes in a colander; sprinkle sugar over potatoes. Set aside until liquid is released from potatoes, 20 to 30 minutes. Drain liquid and dry potatoes well.

Mix potato slices, olive oil, garlic powder, salt, and black pepper in a resealable plastic bag until evenly coated. Spread coated potato slices in a single layer, leaving space around each potato, on the prepared baking sheet.
Bake in the preheated oven for 20 minutes; flip fries and continue baking until crisp and browned, about 20 more minutes.

review.reviewBody: Fantastic!!! Almost skipped the sugar, but saw the caution. Secret process even better than a secret ingredient. Best fries from the oven. We swap in Garlic flavor Stonemill Salt Free Seasoning for salt. Just delicious. This will be in regular rotation for a long time.

This is the best oven fry recipe I have ever tried and tested. So crispy and so much flavor. If you crisp them enough they can trick your mind as a chip truck fry! So delicious, even converted my mother from her own recipe!
Good. But much too sweet for our taste. Will try again with about 1/3 of the Sugar.
My 18 year old daughter gave them an A+! I added some Parmesan to them. Yummy

I made these fries and my family and I are not fans of sweet fries. Kudos to those who do like them. The sweetness took away from the potato. When I want a potato taste I do not think of sweet. I will use this recipe again without sugar.
Perfect, guiltless recipe!
Delicious. It is easy!
Well I have a brand new stove and I made these exactly the way the recipe said to , but 20 more minutes burned my fries so next time I will olny cook them for 20 minutes!

I have made several attempts at oven fries, and these are by far the BEST! I took the advice of another review, and made sure I had plenty of time to prepare and cook the potatoes. I let them sit in the colander for 45 minutes, dried them in paper towel, and baked as directed except I used parchment paper instead of foil. I used too much olive oil, but that was my fault not the recipe! They baked at 425 for 20 minutes, I had to turn up the oven to 450 to finish them in another 20 minutes. It was worth the effort on a weekend, but doubt I would do it on a weeknight!
I have made this a couple times now with Yukon gold and red baking potatoes and this recipe is the bomb! My boys eat this up and love it. The sugar is a brilliant trick and the spices are perfect.
May be a litle time consuming, but oh so worth it. Marinated them an hour before cooking and they came out crispy and delicious.

BEST baked fries EVER. Followed the recipe except the garlic which I do not eat. I have a convection oven so they cooked quicker but turned out amazing. Was sceptical on the sugar as didn’t want sweet fries but rinsed it off and wow.....This is a keeper!!
Great!
Super side dish!! My husband isn't a big fan of potatoes, but asked for this for dinner after having it for the first time last week, was I shocked! And delighted!! Great go-to recipe!
Delicious fries. My family enjoyed the crispness of them as I left them to bake a little longer. I’ll definitely make it again
Wonderful. Make as often as possible. Yum
The extra steps of sugaring and drying the potatoes was rather annoying (at least when my toddler was was being a rascal) but it was worth it! Also served grilled steak, garden peas, & grape salad.

I was skeptical about putting sugar on the sliced potatoes, but followed directions to the letter. They were beyond awesome. Will always use this recipe when making baked French fries. My guests raved about them.
The sugar makes the difference.
no changes addicted to this way of making fries.
Soooo delicious!! Don't leave the sugar out. It was hard for me to turn my fries over, but the result was still AMAZING! ??

These were really good when they were fresh, but they didn't reheat well after being frozen. I experimented with the temps and times a bit but they would either come out soggy or burned. I don't think I'll make these again unless it's with the intention of eating them straight away.

I've made these several times, tasty and delicious every time!
I do find that closer to an hour in the oven for me works better, who knows, could just be the Canadian potatoes.
The flavor was great! I should have flipped them every 5 minutes as they ended up burning. The parts that weren’t burned make me want to try this recipe again!
Best Baked French Fries they are. I sliced the potatoes in thinner slices and it took half the time in prepping as well as baking. They were delicious!
Best Baked French Fries they are. I sliced the potatoes in thinner slices and it took half the time in prepping as well as baking. They were delicious!
Real eat and they turned out beautifully! I like the preparation of tossing them in a ziplock, that makes sure they all get oiled.
Enjoyed. I made the baked fries and served them with my homemade steak and cheese subs. Delicious!
Yummy!
These are amazing! But this is my warning, make sure you don't make too many.....because you will eat them!!

Fantastic fries! They were crispy and delicious... well worth the extra effort of extracting the liquid using sugar. I used russet potatoes and added a chipotle spice blend so that I could lower the sodium content (still got great flavor). The baking time was spot on for me. Will definitely make again.
Super good! I also added parsley and paprika.

I made this last night for dinner cause I forgot to pick up the frozen French fries to accompany our meal after this, I won't be buying any more frozen stuff. My son loved them and he is very picky! Also don't skip the sugar step, I couldn't believe how much liquid was extracted from the potatoes. I used russet potatoes since that's all I had in the pantry. they were delicious! oh make sure you cut the potatoes in even length and thickness to ensure even roasting. This recipe is a keeper!
Very tasty and family loved! This is a nice change from frozen store bought fries.
They were simply delicious. I can't wait to make them again. I used russets because it's what I had.
The most difficult thing to achieve when making baked french fries is getting them crispy. Well, this recipe gets it done! Thanks
I wanted fries but knew there had to be a way to make them without all the oil. This recipe is exactly what I was looking for!
My son loved these!!

Delicious! I made these at 400F because I cooked them the same time as some chicken wings. They had the same required cooking time, just different temps. So after I pulled the wings out, I turned off the oven and switched to the broiler on high for 5-6 minutes, worked like a charm!

Made these last night. Would strongly suggest to either mix the potatoes with olive oil in a bowl vs a bag and take out with tongs before putting on baking sheet. Way too much oil and the potatoes had no “crispness” to them as a result. I would have had to keep them on broil for quite some time to get near that.result - but that would also mean opening up the oven every few minutes to make sure they don’t get torched. Bottom line, ditch the bag and pouring entire contents on baking sheet unless you like soggy fries.
My husband raved about these. Wonderful to find a simple but very tasty recipe we both loved.
l=Loved these fries. They came out really crisp. Next time I'll use less oil.
I made this with and without sugar. Both are great!

I was suspicious at first after many failed attempts at oven-baked fries, but THIS RECIPE rivals the best steak frites I've had at any restaurant. Instead of 6 potatoes, I used 2 Russets (800 grams). I left the spice amounts the same, but reduced the amount of oil (20 grams). The fries were perfectly salty, garlic-y, and peppery from 1 teaspoon of each. My partner and I alternated between dipping in Ketchup and Ranch, and could not decide which was more delicious. This is a keeper of a recipe!
Followed the directions exactly and the fries came out amazing! Definitely following this method from now on.
Don't overbake these, the time given is too much! 20 minutes is ok on the first side, then you only need 10 minutes once flipped to the other side. Yummy with ketchup.
Loved it!
I made it and I'll definitely make it again. Nearly was good as fried french fries, but not quite. But probably much healthier.

These came out great. I had my 3 and a half year old granddaughter help me with this. She sprinkled liberal amounts of sugar on the sliced potatoes. The potatoes released water and after the seasoning was added, I baked these for 45 minutes at 450F. Midway through I flipped the potatoes over. They came out very crispy. There were no left overs. I will definitely make these again.
Love this recipe

So delicious and easy to make. I made them skinnier ( like matchsticks) , cooked them for 20 min one side and just 2 min on other side because they were so skinny. They were a hit. I can see how this recipe you can have fun with by adding cheeses or seasonings to make a wide variety of specialty fries.
I substituted the garlic powder with fresh Rosemary. Everything turned out beautifully. I will make this again! Thank you.
Very good fries! Made them according to recipe. Huge hit with family.
Very good fries! Made them according to recipe. Huge hit with family.
easy to make and a favorite with burgers, steak, or just about anything
Delicious and mom approved. She doesn't like fried foods (or actually they don't like her) and these won her over.
Best fries. I have ever made!!
Tasted really good but didn’t crisp up as I was hoping. I did the sugar thing. Maybe I will cut them thinner next time, will make again
Crust on the outside, creamy on the inside—never better! I’ll do these again!!

I was skeptical to try this because I was concerned the potatoes would turn out sweet-tasting from the sugar sprinkles. But a good rub down of the potatoes to remove it and to dry the wedges proved to be successful. No sweet aftertaste!

The texture of the potatoes were great. A perfect combo of a bit crispy on the outside and soft and cooked-through on the inside. The seasoning was also great. Next time, I will use a little ground rosemary, I think. This one's a keeper!
Definitely the best baked fried I've ever had. Don't forget the sugar. You won't taste the sugar once you rinse the potatoes; just makes them crispier.
This recipe works! I used russet potatoes, thats what I had on hand. Other then that pretty much followed the instructions. Will definitely make again. Thank You for submitting.
Delicious. This recipe is a keeper.
Full five stars. Made these fries with Hebrew national hotdogs. Chicago style. Out of this world good. Used the convection setting for the fries. Got to have this combo once a week!!
These are soo good. I've also used minced garlic instead of powdered. I bake them on a Pampered Chef bar pan... no flipping required.
We love these! I don't use sugar on them but they still come out great. Crispy and so tasty. I make two sheet pans full and each time there are no left overs!
Good flavor, used three baking sheets on three levels to enable the fries space. They should have been crunchier. I left them in an extra 5-6 minutes and will bake longer next time.

Half my kids even liked them. They never like anything that comes from an actual potato. I think I'll just cut them thinner next time. I did up the temp to 450 towards the end. I did save the recipe so I can make them again.
Both of my kids liked these, so I give it 5 starts because they rarely like home fries.
These were great! I made no changes but I will be trying some different ideas.

This is a decent recipe. Most of the fries took a little longer than 40 minutes to bake. The fries had a very good flavor, but I ran out of garlic powder as I was preparing the recipe and only had about half of that called for in the recipe. I leave open the possibility of modifying my rating to five stars if when I prepare it again, the extra garlic powder elevates it.

I made this recipe exactly as instructed and it turned out to be my first successful oven baked fryes. Usually I end up with half mush half burnt disasters, but not this time, I will be making this again. I want to try this recipe with sweet potatoes next time.
Thank you for sharing!
Hard to make in bulk, they turn out the best if they can all lie flat on the plan without being stacked.
Make sure you use a big enough pan so that you just have one single layer. Otherwise, they won’t get crispy. But delicious nevertheless!!
Loved these! Best homemade fries I’ve ever made. I followed recipe exactly, except used russet potatoes because that’s what I had.
best ones so far and easy to make.
made them 3 times before kids figured out these weren't double fried. love them
Worked really well! They were great!
I omitted the sugar and used russet potatoes instead yukon.
Everyone in my family (especially my teenage boys!) loves this. I use about eight large russet potatoes, about a third cup of olive oil, and everything else as normal. This is a fabulous dish!

This was my first time making baked fries and it was a success! The seasoning was just right and the fries were nice and crispy. Adding sugar and then drying them with a towel was a great suggestion. Next time I’ll try making smaller cuts, though.
Made them just like the recipe. good fries

The sugar process is a must I still cant believe how much moisture is drawn out incredible! I broil the last couple of minutes to get that crunch factor, however keeping an eye will help from over cooking.

I was totally surprised how much starch & liquid came out of the potatoes using the sugar. Thought at first , okay we will see but it did work and just rinsed in cold water and dried. I did use olive oil with a bit of butter just to add a buttery flavor and man oh man. Was it good. This is my new recipe for oven baked fries.
Texture was great but waaayyy too peppery for my taste. I would omit the pepper completely next time and also bake less, came out slightly burnt.

These are amazing! I made them with BBQ sandwiches for dinner and my family loved them, even my super picky toddler lol I wanted to try a new recipe because my homemade fries never seem to turn out right, they were good but not great, i was doing everything except putting them in sugar, sugar made a 100% difference.
Perfect Potatoes is a good and basic way to enjoy them with turmeric dip!
Very good! I think I added a little too much oil when I shook them up up in the bag but all in all the to the flavor was delicious..I really think the sugar makes the recipe

Tried this recipe with sweet potatoes.
They were a little soggy, but tasted good.
Good recipe, easy.
Will make again.

Followed directions including spraying aluminum foil. Had to literally peel the potatoes off one by one to flip them. would take a picture, but they look half eaten. Guess I'll keep searchung for decent oven fries, these aren't them.

I've been making these fries for a while using this recipe, this is without a doubt my favorite recipe and a reliable one. They always come out amazing. One thing I like to do after they're done in the oven though is sprinkle with shredded cheese and microwave it for about 40 - 50 seconds and it tastes even better!
Did not like..Will not make again...

You don't need the sugar or the salt; simply dry your newly cut potatoes with a clean tea towel that you can use as your "potato towel" and then coat with oil and spices. They turn out crisp and tasty.
These were very healthy French fries without deep frying saving many calories. They tasted just like deep fried fries. I would make them again.

I don’t know where I went wrong. I cooked these exactly as the recipe stated. Didn’t change one single thing except not cook as long but most of my fries burnt and still tasted a little sweet. I’ll try one more time since so many people were raving about this but I’m unsure if it’s worth the trouble.
No followed recepie to the T they were great

The sugar was such a cool trick, and worked, so I didn't end up with soggy oven fries. This is the only way I'll do oven fries from now on. And I couldn't taste the sugar, but I patted them dry and probably all the sugar melted off or was patted off. Thans for this excellent tip

I loved these! The fries are fabulous! I'll make them again for sure. I made a double batch planning to freeze half. I followed another reviewer - I removed 1 batch halfway through baking, let cool and froze on a cookie sheet. She said to bake from frozen for 20 mins at 400 (flipping halfway) on oiled, foil lined pan.

I was looking for an easy recipe to use up some of the potatoes we have. I followed the directions exactly except used coconut oil since i didn't have any other kind on hand. My husband HATES coconut flavor but he didn't notice and I didn't tell him. My kids liked them and gave them a 4 star. I'm giving a 5 due to taste and super easy to make. I did bake 20 min on each side. The aluminium foil needs the cooking spray as the fries do tend to stick. I also did include the sugar step.
